awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Investigation of Interactions of Temperature, Pore Water Pressure, and Pore Fluid Flow in Soil Media
awd_abstract_narration:
Temperature change induces a variety of changes in soils, including volumetric change in saturated clays and clay mixtures, changes in permeability, and special variation in fluid density leading to induced flow. The aim of this research is to investigate the fundamental interaction of temperature, water pressure, and pore fluid flow in soil through integrated experimental and computational models.  The knowledge generated through this research will be utilized to optimize the design and construction of nuclear waste disposal facilities, geothermal boreholes, and other energy geo-structures.  The outcomes of the research, and the results of advanced numerical model and laboratory controlled experiments, will be essential for applications of thermal-hydraulic-mechanical-chemical (THMC) modeling in civil engineering (e.g., underground structures, deep geothermal power plants, and construction in permafrost areas).   The results of the experimental models can also be useful to predict the permeability changes of landfills due to chemical reactions and daily temperature variations to have a better estimation of leakage based on the temperature dependent permeability.  The expected research findings may also help to improve the current design codes and methodologies for underground structures surrounding heat sources.  The education and outreach activities of this project will provide both K-12 and college students from underrepresented groups with opportunities to be exposed to STEM disciplines and careers.  The personnel on this project will provide guidance to graduate students considering careers in academia and research. This study also help to enhance the research literacy of the Commonwealth of Kentucky, one of the EPSCoR states. 

The goal of this research is to comprehensively study temperature effects on soil behavior.  Soil hydraulic conductivity varies with temperature.  This happens not only because of changes in fluid density and viscosity, temperature might alter the soil fabric and porosity in both sand and clay as well.  Temperature increments in unsaturated media result in drying soil and moisture content reduction close to the heat sources.  However, temperature changes in saturated sand make the spatial variation in fluid mass density. Such a variation results in buoyancy-driven flow and, creates thermally driven pore fluid flow. The thermally induced pore fluid flow in sand facilitates heat transfer in the ground and results in heat convection even under hydrostatic condition.  Therefore, induced pore fluid flow must be considered to accurately model the heat transfer in the ground.  The interaction of heat and fluid flows needs to be investigated in high permeable soil.  On the other hand, heat flow results in permeability variation and volumetric changes which will result in thermal consolidation in low permeable ground (e.g., clay).  Four main tasks are planned to accomplish the research goal: (1) Predicting permeability variation of different soil types (e.g. sand and clay with different void ratios) under different confining stresses using a temperature controlled cell; (2) Analyzing volumetric changes and thermal consolidation for different temperature increments in clays; (3) Studying the effect of thermally induced pore fluid flow on soil temperature response in high permeable soil; and (4) Predicting the interaction of heat and fluid flow in porous media while considering time and temperature dependent soil and fluid properties.  The outcomes of the current study will be useful for Multiphysics and flow in porous media.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Temperature increments in highly permeable soils, such as coarse sands, induce thermally driven pore fluid flow. This thermally induced pore fluid flow in sand facilitates heat transfer in the ground and results in heat convection even under hydrostatic conditions. Therefore, induced pore fluid flow must be considered to accurately model heat transfer in highly permeable ground. On the other hand, thermal loading results in permeability variations and volumetric changes, leading to thermal consolidation in saturated clay or clay mixed with sand under normally consolidated conditions.

The key outcomes of the project are:

  1. The hydraulic conductivity of Kaolin clay increases by approximately 140% to 150% as the soil temperature rises from 20 °C to 80 °C. This increase is primarily attributed to the reduction in the dynamic viscosity of water at higher temperatures. However, the intrinsic permeability of Kaolin clay decreases by about 20% when the soil temperature increases from 20 °C to 80 °C. This reduction in intrinsic permeability is a result of thermal volume reduction, also known as thermal consolidation, in Kaolin clay.
  2. The intrinsic permeability of Kaolin clay continues to decrease for up to 48 hours after initiating the thermal load on the sample. This reduction in permeability over time indicates an ongoing process of thermal consolidation and void ratio reduction within the selected samples.
  3. Experimental observations demonstrate that void ratio reduction (volumetric changes) is independent of thermal loading steps but highly depends on OCR value. The results also indicate a linear relationship between void ratio and the logarithm of temperature. While irreversible contraction is observed after one heating-cooling cycle of normally consolidated clays, highly overconsolidated soil shows irreversible expansion. Results determine no significant volumetric changes with temperature for the sample with OCR equals to 1.6.
  4. The results obtained from the coupled hydrothermal model revealed that intrinsic permeability plays an important role in the coupling effect between heat-induced pore fluid flow and thermal convection. For highly permeable soils, not only is thermal convection of the same magnitude as thermal conduction, but the convection flux is also opposite to the heat conduction flux and accumulates heat close to the thermal source. The impact of natural convection on heat transfer is influenced by two dimensionless numbers (Ra and Co), which account for soil permeability, groundwater velocity, and heat source temperature. The findings suggest that when groundwater velocity is less than 10^-7 m/s, there is no need to consider forced convection in the analysis. Natural convection should only be considered when Ra is greater than or equal to 50. Additionally, in cases where groundwater velocity equals or exceeds 10^-7 m/s, natural convection significantly affects heat transfer only when Co is greater than or equal to 20. Furthermore, the role of natural convection under confined and unconfined surface boundary conditions was examined. It was revealed that, compared to forced convection, natural convection led to an increase in soil temperature at the surface under confined boundary conditions, while it reduced soil temperature at the surface under unconfined conditions.
  5. A fully coupled THM model has been developed in this study. The results determined that considering simplified and constant values of thermal and hydraulic properties of soil-water systems leads to poor predictions of thermal pressurization and stress characteristic alterations in clayey soils due to high thermal loading. The careful evaluation of multiple thermal, hydraulic, and mechanical constitutive models and properties considered in this study showed that the effects of viscosity and the thermal expansion coefficient of water on thermal pressurization and stress characteristics are paramount. It was shown that the inclusion of thermo-plastic deformation is significant during the cooling phase when negative variations of pore water pressure are generated.

The final results of the project help to have a better understanding of heat and fluid flow in sandy soil and thermal consolidation in clays. The results of the current project can help to explore the use of thermally induced volume reduction in clayey soils and identify thermally enhanced prefabricated vertical drains as a ground improvement method. The results of the permeability test on Ottawa sand and Kaolin clay can also be used as input parameters to model energy geo-structures.

The outcomes of the proposed research and the results of the advanced numerical model and laboratory-controlled experiments will be essential for applications of thermo-hydro-mechanical-chemical modeling in, civil engineering (e.g., underground structures, and energy geo-structures) and petroleum engineering(e.g., close to oil wells).

The expected research findings may also help to improve the current design codes and methodologies for underground structures surrounding heat sources.
